comments.body: Is this really noarch python, even with the Java bits?

Thanks for the review @scopatz! 
I think "noarch" should be fine - at least this is what I expect from Java.
The "python" part also is not 100% clear to me, so thanks for asking. I understood the conda-forge documentation that there are no C++ compiled parts - which is true - but I do not know if also the java "compilation" counts here.
As it is basically a performance optimization on the build side I am also fine with removing the "python" part. Can/should I replace it with "noarch generic" then or remove this part completely?

Is the jar just a data-file part of the python package?

Should be fine to regard it as noarch

The jar is created during the [python package installation](https://github.com/nils-braun/dask-sql/blob/main/setup.py#L38) via a [call](https://github.com/nils-braun/dask-sql/blob/main/setup.py#L9) to `mvn` and then specified in the `setup.py` as `package_data` ([link](https://github.com/nils-braun/dask-sql/blob/main/setup.py#L62)).
I honestly do not know if this is the best way to do it... 
But it is not already included in the repo, if this was your question.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +12,16 @@
build:
  noarch: python
  number: 0
  script: {{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . --no-deps -vv
